Hi, all. We missed the White House egg roll. It's too far away from our home in Ohio, and this was a cold Easter. I would point folks to the Family Pride Coalition website: http://www.familypride.org/eggroll/ 
 
 The Family Pride Coalition organized the gay participation in the egg roll event, last year and this year.  Apparently there were other groups doing a bomb protest with children at the same time, and they drew a lot of fire from people who felt that their protest was inappropriate.

Just the one-on-one contact between our families and other families helps to bridge gaps and to build positive relations. Our families have been invisible for too long. Plus I think the egg roll would be fun for kids from all kinds of families.

 The Million Man March was more than a bunch of people walking, but it wasn't exactly a protest either. It was a statement, which is not necessarily a protest. In part it was a statement of commitment by African American men to their families and communities. 
 
 Being visible is only a protest if people are protesting something. In the case of the egg roll, it was simply a statement that, "We are here." 
 
 Gay parents always pay attention to our own children. The point of participation in the egg roll was not to convince other families that gay families are "good." It was to be visible to other families and to get to know other families. I think the more we interact with other families and give our children the opportunity to interact with others, the better for our children. 
 
 I am an adoptive parent, and my child is from Guatemala. I belong to a group of families with children from Guatemala. We go to events together all the time, and we identify ourselves as families with children from Guatemala. Is that a protest? No. Are we being visible? Yes. We want people to know that there are families with children from Guatemala, and we want to interact with other families and also to enable our children to have a good time. Are we using our children "to prove something to others?" I don't think so. We are interacting with others. It's similar to what the gay families did at the egg roll.
